Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Expectation2: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation2: An automated compliance system flags any minute of unscheduled downtime for possible disciplinary action.
Story: I glance at the clock on my computer screen—my break is over in two minutes. My headset itches against my ear, but I can’t take it off yet. Just as I’m about to log back in, I hear the front door creak. My boyfriend walks in, shoulders slumped, eyes red. He doesn’t say anything, just drops his bag and sits heavily on the couch. I know that look; he’s had a rough day. I want to go to him, to wrap my arms around him and listen, to be the girlfriend he needs right now. But my heart pounds as I remember the compliance system at work. If I’m even a minute late logging back in, the system will flag me, and I can’t afford another warning. My job expects me to be punctual, to put work first during my hours. But my partner expects me to be present, to care, to support him when he’s hurting. I stand frozen between the living room and my desk, torn by the demands of both worlds, feeling the weight of letting someone down no matter what I choose.
